TR: Then, on the morning of the second day, having performed his regular obligatory rituals, the Guru should ask his disciples about the dreams of the night and cause them to see the maṇḍala.
TEXT: liṅgaṃ svapno vidhisthasya na kvacid vā tu doṣajaḥ ||
TR: For one who abides by the injunctions (vidhisthasya), dreams are the signs of the future (eṣya°) ripenings of [the fruits of] actions, whether good or bad. Or not, in some cases, when [such dreams] are produced by some [ritual or other problem-causing] fault.
NOTE: The expression vidhisthasya could conceivably mean “of one who is involved in [this particular] ritual [of initiation].” As for doṣa, it may refer to ritual and other problems that are liable to cause the initiation ritual to go awry.
TEXT: yadvā tu prakṛtir yena dhātunā vāpi dūṣitaḥ |
TR: Alternatively [it may simply be] the nature [of the dreamer that produces his dreams], or [the dream] may be spoiled by the humours [in his body] (dhātunā). [The guru] sees the transformations of those [various factors] in the dream of the individual soul as though they were directly visible before him.
TEXT: yaṃ ca supto ’rtham{ }ādāya duṣṭaṃ vā yadi vā śubham |
TR: Whatever thing the sleeping person receives in the dream, whether bad or auspicious, that sequence of thoughts appears as though it were directly visible before one.

Both these [good and bad] dream-cognitions are not considered in this scriptural tradition as being like [cognitions] in cases where the light [of cognition] deviates [from reality] because the sense faculties are corrupted or because what is to be cognised is very far away.

Therefore when somebody whose bodily humours are in balance sees something in a dream, whether auspicious or inauspicious, [even if] he is devoid of faith, [he will find that to be] true, without exception.
Crossing a river or the ocean or a jungle, mounting upon an elephant or a horse or upon a flying palace (vimāne), escaping from a prison.
TEXT: snānaṃ śivārccanaṃ vahnau tarpaṇaṃ darśanaṃ satām |
TR: Bathing; venerating Śiva; pouring oblations into the fire; having audience with good people, or with [Śiva’s] gaṇas, or with gods; drinking nectar; flying in the sky.
Seeing such like dreams is indicative of good auspices in the case of one desirous of liberation. The opposite [of such dreams] is indicative of undesirable [consequences], for instance:
Mounting upon a donkey or camel; falling into a pit or into mud or from a mountain; breaking one's limbs; meeting enemies; hunger and thirst; weariness.
TEXT: gamitasya paraṃ bhāgaṃ dadhnaḥ prāśanam uttamam ||
TR: Eating most excellently (uttamam) curd that is juicy (sarasasya), well-formed (sujātasya), which has been caused [because of its fatty content] to rise to the topmost part [of the vessel] (gamitasya paraṃ bhāgam) by itself (kevalasya), or with rice.
Eating the naturally ripening fruits of mangos and the like, having climbed up oneself, is a sign [of the acquisition] of special powers, for one who wishes to attain them.
NOTE: For the conjectural emendation to \skt{cūtādīnām}, see the clearly related passage in Uttara-Kāmika 22 (10c–11): cūtādi puṇyavṛkṣāṇāṃ saphalanāṃ tu darśanam | teṣām ārohaṇaṃ śastaṃ tatphalānāṃ ca saṃgrahaḥ | teṣāṃ ca bhakṣaṇaṃ śastaṃ śailaharmyāśvahastinām
APP: \vcd goḥ pānaṃ \conj; goḥ pāna \msApc, go pāna \msAac
TR: This dream is auspicious (bhavyaḥ) for [the acquisition of] special powers: the fact of (yad) drinking milk from a reddish cow that lactates (prasnutāyāḥ) by happenstance (yadṛcchayā), because of the playfulness of her calf (vatsalīlayā).
NOTE: Cf.\ prasavo vātha caitāsāṃ bhūtiliṅgam iti smṛtam / payasaḥ pāṭalāyā goḥ pānaṃ yad vatsalīlayā (Kāmikāgama, Uttara, 22:15; Muktabodha e-text!!!). Here perhaps prasavo could be an error for prasnavo ?
TEXT: If one sees these things and they are acquired with difficulty but one loses them (aprāptiḥ) or they are taken away, [then such a] dream is indicative of [attaining] the final aim [of liberation].
NOTE: The same verse occurs, with an important, but probably originally accidental change, in Uttara-Kāmika 22:53: dṛṣṭānām api caiteṣāṃ prāptānāṃ ca kathañcana / aprāptir apahāraś ca svapne ’niṣṭārthasūcakaḥ
TR: Having heard the dreams recounted by those [disciples] who have bathed and who are wearing clean garments, he should rejoice at the auspicious ones among them and then perform countermeasures for the others.
TEXT: ghṛtaṃ dūrvvāṃ madhu kṣīraṃ śatahomāya kāpilam |
TR: The maṇḍala may be shown to one who has had an undesirable dream (aniṣṭasvapnasya) once he has offered (ādiśya) ghee, Dūrvā-grass, honey, [and] milk from a tawny cow, [enough] for one hundred oblations.
[It should be] square, with four gateways, with even lines [drawn] outside the maṇḍala (bahiḥpuram). Inside it, [there should be a] circle [containing] an eight-petalled lotus with a pericarpel.

Similarly (?) there should be four doors, [each] made using a fourth part [of the length of the side (?)] of the maṇḍala. The maṇḍala should be eight cubits [across], or half of that, having beautiful pathways.
[It should be] bright, adorned with delicate (komalābhiḥ) lines of powder that are white, red and black, that are not too thin, or too broad, or crooked.

On the outside, it should be encircled (°veṣṭitam) with [decorative patterns of] leaves and creepers and the like (pattravallyādi°), which should not be too long, richly (gāḍham) colourful with [various] powders. Entrance should be through the western gateway.
It should have four [lion-]feet with lofty heads, bright, and supported (uddhṛtaiḥ) with cross-struts, adorned all around with a wheel (nemyā).
It should shine with petals (dalaiḥ) that have the form of regal serpents’ hoods whose summits are slightly inclined, and with gaps in between them that are dark and well arranged (suvibhaktaiḥ).

[It should be drawn] with filaments whose shadow/radiance occupies a third [of each petal] from the base of the petal. At the tip, in the middle and at the base, [the filaments should be] yellow, reddish and white [respectively].
It should be ornamented in the middle with a yellow lotus, measuring six parts [of the maṇḍala?] with a beautiful pericarpel.

It should have the gaps [in between the petals and such] wiped with a cloth that is wet with moist fragrant unguent. [It should be furnished] with hanging garlands of flowers that are pleasing and various.
Well-fashioned in this way, this seat of Śiva (sārvam) bestows compassion on all. When those who know its special properties see it, they share in the pleasure, respectfully.
NOTE: The use of the instrumental in tadviśeṣajñaiḥ seems not to be warranted by the construction. Have we misunderstood something ?
TR: Then, removing obstacles (?nirodham), being pure and bathed, with senses controlled, when five “hours” have passed, once he has performed his afternoon duties, ...
… taking permission for performing a beautiful pūjā from those who know such [matters] and who are not careless (aprāmādinaḥ)...
NOTE: We are assuming that saparyā is used as a synonym of pūja and here is preceded by the prefix su-, which makes the first s retroflex. The second half is not clear to us at the moment (July 2020).
TR: … causing all other noise to disappear far away by means of the resounding of the Nāndī-hymn, he should venerate the doorkeepers, making their bodies directly visible to himself by means of visualisation,
NOTE: We guess that Nāndī refers to a hymn or shout of praise that the rituals intones. But perhaps it is something else. A bell ?
TR: He should invariably look around the inner space (garbham), as though never [seen] before, with its arrangements (bhaktibhiḥ), which gives joy to the beholder, even if he has seen it time and again.

He should enter, in a manner qualified by his desire to bring about a union (sandhānakāmam) thus (iti): “Today (adya), being full to the brim (upabṛṃhitaḥ) with Śiva's glory, I shall cause bound souls to to be released by means of this (amuyā) collection of equipment (sāmagryā).”

Facing north, as before, he should be seated; having made his body into Śiva [by the process known as sakalīkaraṇa], performing (°kāraṇaḥ) [the three types of] “sacrifice” [respectively] in the heart, navel and forehead.
NOTE: If we have understood this correctly, the last quarter alludes to the notion that internal mental pūjā, homa and dhyāna are to be performed respectively in the heart, the navel and between the brows. Cf.\ Sārdhatriśatikālottara 2:13: hṛdaye'rcāvidhānan tu nābhau homaṃ prakalpayet | lalāṭe ceśvaraṃ dhyāyed varadaṃ sarvatomukham || It thus tells us that the initiating ācārya should perform internal worshiop consisting in internal pūjā, homa and dhyāna. What is still problematic is the use here of \skt{kāraṇa}: can it really used in the masculine to describe the “agent-cause” here?
TR: Having performed protection [of the ritual space] and anusandhāna (?), having purified the [ritual substances that are the] supports for properties, [and] after the worship [that constitutes the purification] of the self
NOTE: We have no plausible idea about what anusandhāna means here. We suppose that the ritual act normally known as dravyaśuddhi might be referred to by viśodhitaguṇāśrayaḥ. We guess that ātmapūjā may refer to ātmaśuddhi, which is a possible way of referring to bhūtaśuddhi. Thus far, three of the well five śuddhis have been mentioned: sthānaśuddhi, dravyaśuddhi and bhūtaśuddhi. As for śodhyam adhvānam, it is syntactically problematic, since it is accusative, but seems not to be the object to a main verb.
TR: After venerating [Śiva/himself] ornamented with a turban along with the śivāṅga-mantras in [his own] body, he should prepare the “hand of Śiva” [by laying mantras upon it] while bearing in mind the kāraṇa-deities.
NOTE: Perhaps we should correct to uṣṇīṣabhūṣaṇaḥ ? CHECK procedures given elsewhere for the śivahasta.
TR: Decoration is something that wards off the mass of bonds form the thought-processes of souls. He should prepare the maṇḍala for Śiva [in such a way that it is] full of the kalās that make up all the universe.

Among those, one should place [the kalā called] Nivṛtti in the powder (rajasi) that has the [black] colour of pure collyrium, [one should place] Pratiṣṭhā in the yellow-orpiment-coloured [powder], Vidyā in the red-lead-coloured [powder], Śānti in the white [powder] and Śāntyatītā in the [green] parakeet-coloured [powder], each with its proper mantra.
APP: \va site śāntiṃ śukaprakhye \conj; śite sānti sukayakhye \msA
TR: Having venerated [Śiva who is] the Cause of causes although he is in the pot, …
NOTE: Perhaps the api instead simply functions as a connective particle “and”? But there is already a ca.
TR: … and having shared in the delight (abhinandya ca), and having venerated Nandi and [Mahākāla] who possesses the skull-bowl on the doorposts in due order,
Entering the maṇḍala (?) of Śiva through the western gateway...

[[He should]] not [[disturb the maṇḍala]] using flowers, or fragrances, nor unbroken rice, water or the like, or any factors of other types that would cause the composition of powders to be disrupted...
NOTE: Testimonium: We find the following quotation ad ĪŚGDP KP 18:1–2: atra brahmaśambhuḥ --- na puṣpair na ca gandhena salilena vā / rajasāṃ racanābhaṅgaṃ kuryāt
TEXT: racanāsu ca vastrāṇāṃ puṣpadāmnā<ṃ> ca maṇḍape |
TR: … one hundred oblations for destroying [what is presaged by] inauspicious dreams. Having performed each one of these oblations with the astra, for the sake of illuminating the mantras...
After bringing the bali inside (?) for Rudra and others and offering, he should cause the disciples to approach Śiva in due order and cause them to enter [the sacrificial space/maṇḍala].
NOTE: We do not understand the above. It is also possible that rudrādibhyo balim... is to be construed instead with dīpanāya ca in the previous verse.
TR: As before, he should make ready the Śiva-hand for the bound soul whose body has been purified and who is under direction [of the guru] (śāsanasthasya) on the southern side [of the maṇḍala] outside the maṇḍala (purāt).
NOTE: Perhaps the conjecure śāsanasthasya is wrong. Perhaps instead the initiand is qualified as sitting in some particular way outside the maṇḍala.
TR: After performing circumambulation of Śambhu in the pot, and instructing [the disciple to perform] a prostration and a pūjā, he should approach the vicinity of the fire-pit.
TEXT: āhūya svasya pūrveṇa kṛtvā sannihitaṃ paśum ||
TR: After giving guest-water to Agni (tejasāṃ nidheḥ) who is in the flaming fire there [in the fire-pit], he should call the bound soul, placing him near to himself on the eastern side.
NOTE: Where is the guru standing relative to the fire-pit ?
TR: After joining the [central] tubes of himself and the disciple by placing a blade of Darbha grass, he should cause [the disciple] to worship Śiva after perfoming a hundred oblations [into the fire].
NOTE: Underneath pāsamālādyaṃ, in the bottom margin, there is a marginal note that is largely broken off. We can probably read the word śiṣyam, which is followed by 3 or 4 further akṣaras that are now illegible.
TR: Using a blade of kuśa-grass, he renders the garland of cords and so forth [in which the disciple’s soul is installed] such that they flow along the same central tube [as the disciple and the guru], worships it as before and purifies his bonds.
Some of these [bonds] are common[ly experienced]; others are not common[ly experienced]. [Yet] others are of both types [simultaneously], according to whether they are external or internal.

The [evolutes of Māyā known as] Kalā [and the rest] are a common[ly experienced bond]; karman is held to be an uncommon one; and Mala is of both natures, [in accordance with whether or not it is] impelled [to be active] by the power of Śiva's Śakti.

It comes to outward expression in accordance whether or not there is a relation of experienced and experiencer, because it is a causal factor in experience, since it attaches itself to sentient [souls].
TEXT: mantrāḥ padāni varṇṇāś ca bhoktṛbhogyasya bhojakāḥ |
TR: Mantras, words [of the vyomavyāpi], syllables cause the experience of what must be experienced by the experiencer. The experience of past actions is accomplished by mantras and fire in the pyre because of [the experiencer’s] desire for objects of experience.
TEXT: tasya cāyatanaṃ kāryaṃ sādhanaṃ karaṇāni ca |
TR: Bearing all of this in one’s mind, which has received the grace of scripture, one should perform one of the various types of initation, [choosing the type] with regard to the type of person who is to receive grace.

[Initiation that is] for obtaining [pre-liberation] desires (kāmikī) is inflected (rañjitā) as Śivadharma-type and Lokadharma-type. [Initiation generally] is one (ekā), [even though] it purifies by cutting [bonds] on [any one of] several cosmic paths; it is held to be fourfold [if we include also the two naiṣthika types].
The naiṣṭhika type [of initiation] is of two kinds, known as Seedless and Seeded. In accordance with the various [types of] persons who are to be purified, ????
TEXT: aśaivam aśubhaṃ karma śodhyate na śubhaṃ yayā |
lokadharmīti sā jñeyā tadvac chaivam athetarā ||
TR: That [initiation] by which the impure, bad karman is purified, but not the pure [karman], is to be understood to be the Lokadharmī. Now the other one [namely Śivadharmī, is that by which] pure (śaivam) [karman] similarly [is purified].

That by which optionally some world, either one or many, is protected in which there is excellent experience in a certain tattva, such an initiation is [known by a name that is] qualified by that [tattva or world].
NOTE: Perhaps we should emend to tattvaṃ prakṛṣṭabhogaṃ vā, so that we could then understand tattvaṃ vā bhuvanaṃ vā. In other words, this might be about a dīkṣā that leads the initiate only to one or many tattvas or one or many bhuvanas in which there are excellent enjoyments to be had.
TR: The “seed” [here] means the [post-initiatory] rules, together with codes of conduct. The “seeded” [type of initiation] is accompanied by that [“seed”]. The “seedless” [type of initiation] is free of that [“seed”] because of its force being consumed in the fire of mantras.

Next (atha), after focussing on/ resorting to (āśritya) the base (mūlam) of the path that is chosen [from among the six possible cosmic paths], in order to cause the brahmin (?) to reach the place [in the cosmos] that he desires, one should meditate upon the particular portion [of the path] that he is intended to experience.
NOTE: We are particularly uncertain about dvijanmanaḥ here. Does Brahmaśambhu consider that each initiand becomes ritually speaking a brahmin in the course of the ritual because of the rite of dvijatvāpādana ?
TR: [That place (sthānam)], which simultaneously (samakālam) contains the divisions of the other cosmic paths (mārgāntarakalāgarbham), is caused to reach (gamitam) a state of transformation (pariṇāmam) by the various (vicitreṇa) fruits of past actions (karmaṇā), along with the births [that that karman entails] (sajanmanā). [The corresponding divisions of the other paths are] as follows (yathā):
NOTE: The interpretation is uncertain.
TR: The tattva of Earth [in the tattvādhvan], and the sound KA [in the varṇādhvan], and [the first] twenty-eight words [in the padādhvan], [the first] two mantras [in the mantrādhvan], [and the first] one hundred and thirty-nine worlds [literally: two hundred minus sixty-one].
NOTE: CHECK parallels for these correspondances !
TEXT: avalokya nivṛttau tāṃ bhittvā cānupaviśya ca |
TR: Seeing [the above divisions of the other cosmic paths] inside [the kalā called] Nivṛtti, one should cut that [kalā off from the thread on which the cosmos and the initiand's soul have been laid] and, without sitting down (anupaviśya), he should take hold of it and place it in the fire, thinking [of it] as (iti) Śivaśakti.
NOTE: The interpretation is tentative, and we are not sure about whether what is placed in the fire is thought to be Śivaśakti (or Śiva and Śakti), or whether it is the fire that is to be thought of as Śivaśakti. This last option is suggested by the feminines in the next verse.
TR: Next (ataḥ), in that [fire identified as Śivaśakti] which has been worshipped and satisfied with ghee, one should complete/perfect the joining of the soul (paśum) [with the next level of the cosmos] by means of a pentad of oblations.
NOTE: The above tentative interpretation presupposes that saṃskuryāt takes a double accusative and governs both yojanam and paśum. Alternatively, perhaps one could emend paśum to paśoḥ. Cf. Check SP, III, pp.~281-285.
TEXT: jyeṣṭhā vāmā ca raudrī ca śaktayo ’mūś śivasya hi |
viyoge yoga uddhāre vihanyante na kutracit ||
TR: Jyeṣṭhā, Vāmā, Raudrī. These are the three Powers of Śiva, as is well known (hi). [They act respectively] in disjoining, in joining, in lifing up. They cannot be opposed/vanquished in any situation.
TEXT: na ca sīmantasaṃkalpe vaicitryā karmaṇāṃ gate ||
